In the English tongue he found guilt waiting for him. Renaissance writers turned him into a warning: the worker of hollow deeds. The Reformation made him blush—the new world wanted feeling, and he had only form.

Then came the factories. The machines welcomed him home. Every lever pulled, every stamp struck—done through, done well, done empty. The virtue of completion returned, but without pride. He had become the rhythm of repetition.

Now he lives in notifications and signatures. He sends the email, taps the emoji, finishes the task. Still functioning, still performing. The discipline of Rome survives—but the soul of it has gone missing.
